definition: Specialized biological structures and tissues that perform specific functions within living organisms.

positive_examples: The heart pumps blood throughout the circulatory system.
Her vocal cords vibrated as she sang the high note.
The doctor examined the patient's nervous system for damage.
Fish spawn contains thousands of eggs with nutrient-rich yolks.
His bicep muscle contracted as he lifted the weight.
The reproductive organs produce gametes for fertilization.
negative_examples: She broke her arm bone in the accident.
The skin on his face was sunburned.
He cut his finger and blood dripped out.
Her hair grew longer over the summer.
The dentist examined her teeth for cavities.
He felt the cartilage in his knee joint.
training_hints.disambiguation: Not to be confused with: Bone, Skin, Hair, Teeth, Cartilage

opposite_reasoning: InorganicMatter provides the strongest semantic opposition to OrgansAndSystems. It captures multiple dimensions of opposition: (1) organic vs inorganic chemistry, (2) living vs non-living, (3) biologically organized vs unorganized, and (4) functional biological structures vs non-functional matter. This opposition is well-established in SUMO ontology and provides clear distributional separation for Fisher-LDA. The animate/inanimate distinction is fundamental and will create strong centroid separation for concept steering.
